question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Let

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & a & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}\]

where \emph{a} is a real number.

\textbf{(c)} For what values of \emph{a} (if any) is \emph{cond(A) =
1/2}? Give a reason.
sols:
Recall that

$\text{cond}(A) = \left \| A \right \|\left \| A^{-1} \right \|$

Now, since A is diagonal matrix, it is easy to find $A^{-1}$.

$A^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{a} &0 \\
0& 0 & \frac{1}{2}
\end{bmatrix}$

If $\left | a \right |> 1$, $\left \| A^{-1} \right \| =1$ since
$\max\left \{ \left | 1 \right |,\left | \frac{1}{a} \right |,\left | \frac{1}{2} \right | \right \} =1$.

And $\left \| A \right \|\geq 2$ since
$\max\left \{ \left | 1 \right |,\left | a \right |,\left | 2\right | \right \} \geq 2$.

Thus, $\left \| A^{-1} \right \|\left \| A \right \| \geq 2.$

Therefore, it is impossible to get $\text{cond}(A) = \frac{1}{2}$.

If $\left | a \right |\leq 1$, $\left \| A \right \|=2$ since
$\max\left \{ \left | 1 \right |,\left | a \right |,\left | 2\right | \right \} =2$.

And $\left \| A^{-1} \right \|\geq 1$ since
$\max\left \{ \left | 1 \right |,\left | \frac{1}{a} \right |,\left | \frac{1}{2} \right | \right \} \geq 1.$

Thus, $\left \| A^{-1} \right \|\left \| A \right \| \geq 2.$

Hence, again it is impossible to get $\text{cond}(A) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Therefore, there is no such value a which gives
$\text{cond}(A) =\frac{1}{2}$
hints:
Break this problem up into cases when $\displaystyle a > 1$ and when
$\displaystyle a \leq 1$. Compute the norms of \emph{A} and its inverse
in each case and try to show this situation is impossible.
